--- title: "Hands-on Exercise 1" editor: visual --- # **Part 1: Basics of Using Geospatial Data** The purpose of this exercise is to practice the basics of using geospatial data in R. ### Packages Used `sf` is used to manipulate geospatial data and `tidyverse` for aspatial data. `kableExtra` makes tables with nicer formating. ## Importing and Preparing Data ### Loading Data Let's load the geospatial data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source `D:\lins-92\ISSS624\Hands-on_EX01\data\geospatial' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33 Projected CRS: SVY21 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cyclingpath = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "CyclingPath") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `CyclingPath' from data source `D:\lins-92\ISSS624\Hands-on_EX01\data\geospatial' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 1625 features and 2 fields Geometry type: LINESTRING Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 12711.19 ymin: 28711.33 xmax: 42626.09 ymax: 48948.15 Projected CRS: SVY21 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} preschool = st_read("data/geospatial/pre-schools-location-kml.kml") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source `D:\lins-92\ISSS624\Hands-on_EX01\data\geospatial\pre-schools-location-kml.kml' using driver `KML' Simple feature collection with 1359 features and 2 fields Geometry type: POINT Dimension: XYZ Bounding box: xmin: 103.6824 ymin: 1.248403 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134 z_range: zmin: 0 zmax: 0 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 ``` ::: ::: We can see that each file has a different geometry type to represent different types of features. We can also see that `mpsz` and `cyclingpath` both have the same projected CRS of SVY21 but preschools has a geodetic CRS of WGS 84. These refer to the coordinate systems to model geographic location and how to represent this information on a flat surface. [Here](https://www.esri.com/arcgis-blog/products/arcgis-pro/mapping/gcs_vs_pcs/) is a detailed explanation on why coordinate systems are needed and the difference between a geodetic CRS (GCS) and projected CRS (PCS). ### Checking the Data The `st_geometry` command displays the geometry information of a spatial dataset. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} st_geometry(mpsz) ``` ::: {.cell-output ````` ::: ::: We can also create simple plots of spatial data using the base R `plot` function. We can use indexing to indicate the variable to group by. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(mpsz["CA_IND"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_EX01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Fixing the Projections The `st_crs` displays the details of a spatial dataset's projection. In this example, the EPSG code has been wrongly specified and needs to be corrected. The `st_set_crs` command only changes the code but does not actually change the coordinate system. It is only used to correcting wrongly specified projection information. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} st_crs(mpsz) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Coordinate Reference System: User input: SVY21 wkt: PROJCRS["SVY21", BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21[WGS84]", DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984", ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]], ID["EPSG",6326]], PRIMEM["Greenwich",0, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]]], CONVERSION["unnamed", METHOD["Transverse Mercator", ID["EPSG",9807]], PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433], ID["EPSG",8801]], PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433], ID["EPSG",8802]], PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1, SCALEUNIT["unity",1], ID["EPSG",8805]], PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1], ID["EPSG",8806]], PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1], ID["EPSG",8807]]], CS[Cartesian,2], AXIS["(E)",east, ORDER[1], LENGTHUNIT["metre",1, ID["EPSG",9001]]], AXIS["(N)",north, ORDER[2], LENGTHUNIT["metre",1, ID["EPSG",9001]]]] ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz <- st_set_crs(mpsz, 3414) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: st_crs<- : replacing crs does not reproject data; use st_transform for that ``` ::: ::: To change the coordinate system (called transformation or projection), we use the the `st_transform` function. We will use this function to transform the preschool dataset to the same projection system as the other 2 layers (SVY21). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} preschool <- st_transform(preschool, crs=3414) ``` ::: ### Transforming Aspatial Data to Geospatial Data Sometimes we have datasets that have spatial information (e.g. latitude and longitude) that are not already in geospatal file formats (shp, gpkg, kml). We will need to import them as aspatial data first then specify which variables contain the geometries and how to represent these data spatially (ie. the coordinate system). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} listings <- read_csv("data/aspatial/listings.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 4252 Columns: 16 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (5): name, host_name, neighbourhood_group, neighbourhood, room_type dbl (10): id, host_id, latitude, longitude, price, minimum_nights, number_o... date (1): last_review ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(listings) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 4,252 Columns: 16 $ id 50646, 71609, 71896, 71903, 275343, 275… $ name "Pleasant Room along Bukit Timah", "Ens… $ host_id 227796, 367042, 367042, 367042, 1439258… $ host_name "Sujatha", "Belinda", "Belinda", "Belin… $ neighbourhood_group "Central Region", "East Region", "East … $ neighbourhood "Bukit Timah", "Tampines", "Tampines", … $ latitude 1.33432, 1.34537, 1.34754, 1.34531, 1.2… $ longitude 103.7852, 103.9589, 103.9596, 103.9610,… $ room_type "Private room", "Private room", "Privat… $ price 80, 178, 81, 81, 52, 40, 72, 41, 49, 49… $ minimum_nights 90, 90, 90, 90, 14, 14, 90, 8, 14, 14, … $ number_of_reviews 18, 20, 24, 48, 20, 13, 133, 105, 14, 1… $ last_review 2014-07-08, 2019-12-28, 2014-12-10, 20… $ reviews_per_month 0.22, 0.28, 0.33, 0.67, 0.20, 0.16, 1.2… $ calculated_host_listings_count 1, 4, 4, 4, 50, 50, 7, 1, 50, 50, 50, 4… $ availability_365 365, 365, 365, 365, 353, 364, 365, 90, … ``` ::: ::: From the glimpse, we can see that the latitude and longitude variables contain the spatial information we need. The units used are decimal degrees. Now let's use the `st_as_sf` function to transform the listings dataset into geospatial data. Use the `coords` argument to specify the x and y coordinates (longitude then latitude) respectively. We assume that the original coordinate system was WGS84 (EPSG 4326) and reproject it to SVY21 (EPSG 3414). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} listings_sf <- st_as_sf(listings, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) %>% st_transform(crs=3414) ``` ::: ## Simple Geoprocessing ### Buffers Buffers create a zone around a feature. It is used in geospatial analyses in conjunction with other functions to measure access to amenities (e.g. how many households are within 500m proximity to an MRT station?). The function is `st_buffer`. In this example, we want to calculate the area of land that needs to be set aside for to 5m wide cycling paths.. The original cycling path layer is a polyline dataset which has no width so we need to use create a buffer first then calculate area using the `st_area` function. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} buffer_cycling <- st_buffer(cyclingpath, dist=5, nQuadSegs = 30) buffer_cycling$area = st_area(buffer_cycling) sum(buffer_cycling$area) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 773143.9 [m^2] ``` ::: ::: ### Point-in-Polygon Counts Counting the number of points (features) in a polygon is another common geoprocessing tool. We use the `st_intersects` function to relate the point and polygon layers spatially. It will output a list of points located within each polygon (by their respective indices). The lengths function from base R is used to find the number of elements (ie pre-schools) in each polygon. In this example, we will count the number of pre-schools in each subzone. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz <- mpsz %>% mutate(preschools = lengths(st_intersects(x=mpsz,y=preschool))) plot(mpsz["preschools"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_EX01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Part 2: Choropleth Maps This part is to practice creating choropleth maps in R using the `tmap` package. ### Packages Used For this exercise, we use another new package `tmap` which allows more customisation when drawing maps compared to the base R `plot` function. ## Importing and Preparing Data ### Loading and Manipulating Data This exercise uses the `mpsz` dataset from Part 1 and a new attribute dataset containing population data by subzone. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} popdata <- read_csv("data/aspatial/respopagesextod2011to2020.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 984656 Columns: 7 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (5): PA, SZ, AG, Sex, TOD dbl (2): Pop, Time ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(popdata) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 984,656 Columns: 7 $ PA "Ang Mo Kio", "Ang Mo Kio", "Ang Mo Kio", "Ang Mo Kio", "Ang Mo K… $ SZ "Ang Mo Kio Town Centre", "Ang Mo Kio Town Centre", "Ang Mo Kio T… $ AG "0_to_4", "0_to_4", "0_to_4", "0_to_4", "0_to_4", "0_to_4", "0_to… $ Sex "Males", "Males", "Males", "Males", "Males", "Males", "Males", "M… $ TOD "HDB 1- and 2-Room Flats", "HDB 3-Room Flats", "HDB 4-Room Flats"… $ Pop 0, 10, 30, 50, 0, 0, 40, 0, 0, 10, 30, 60, 0, 0, 40, 0, 0, 10, 30… $ Time 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011, 2011,… ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(popdata, n=5) %>% kable() %>% kable_styling() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

````` ::: ::: For this exercise, we will only be using the 2020 data. We need to relate the attribute data to the `mpsz` dataset. First, we need to manipulate the attribute data to create the following variables: - YOUNG: age group 0 to 4 until age group 20 to 24 - ECONOMYACTIVE: age group 25-29 until age group 60-64 - AGED: age group 65 and above - TOTAL: all age group - DEPENDENCY: the ratio between young and aged against economy active group ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pop2020 <- popdata %>% filter(Time==2020) %>% group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>% summarise(POP = sum(Pop)) %>% ungroup() %>% pivot_wider(names_from = AG, values_from = POP) %>% mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[3:6])+ rowSums(.[12])) %>% mutate(ECONOMYACTIVE = rowSums(.[7:11]) + rowSums(.[13:15])) %>% mutate(AGED=rowSums(.[16:21])) %>% mutate(TOTAL=rowSums(.[3:21])) %>% mutate(DEPENDENCY = (YOUNG + AGED)/ ECONOMYACTIVE) %>% select(PA, SZ, YOUNG, ECONOMYACTIVE, AGED, TOTAL, DEPENDENCY) %>% mutate(across(PA:SZ, toupper)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `summarise()` has grouped output by 'PA', 'SZ'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. ``` ::: ::: Join the attribute data to the `mpsz` data by SZ. In the previous step, we manipulated this variable to be uppercase to match with the `mpsz` file. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_pop2020 <- left_join(x=mpsz, y=pop2020, by= c("SUBZONE_N" = "SZ")) ``` ::: ## Choropleth Maps ### Basic Map A basic choropleth map with no customisations can be created using the `qtm` function. It uses a number of defaults which may not always be useful depending on the dataset. In the example below, the pretty breaks result in a map which is not informative because of the distribution of dependency ratio. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tmap_mode("plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` tmap mode set to plotting ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} qtm(mpsz_pop2020, fill = "DEPENDENCY") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_EX01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### More Customisations `tmap` also allows us to customise each aspect of the map more finely. The code chunk below uses the same dependency ratio data as the above map but splits by quantiles instead to show the distribution more clearly. Other customisations create map elements like title, map scale, map grid and compass. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+ tm_fill("DEPENDENCY", style = "quantile", palette = "Blues", title = "Dependency ratio") + tm_layout(main.title = "Distribution of Dependency Ratio by planning subzone", main.title.position = "center", main.title.size = 1.2, legend.height = 0.45, legend.width = 0.35, frame = TRUE) + tm_borders(alpha = 0.5) + tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) + tm_scale_bar() + tm_grid(alpha =0.2) + tm_credits("Source: Planning Sub-zone boundary from Urban Redevelopment Authorithy (URA)\n and Population data from Department of Statistics DOS", position = c("left", "bottom")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_EX01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
